summary: RESULTS rOC/Us183–241 is more neurovirulent than rOC/ATCC in mice. variant harboring two point mutations in the viral spike (S) glycoprotein showed a significant increase in virus-induced neuronal cell mortality compared to the reference variant (rOC/ATCC) (14). some other variants of HCoV-OC43 were shown to have different levels of neurovirulence in infected mice. rOC/Us183–241 is more neurovirulent than rOC/ATCC in infected mice. we measured infectious viral particles in brain and spinal cord every 2 days. rOC/Us183–241 could be cleared more rapidly than the wild-type virus. rOC/Us183–241 is one of the first regions where HCoV-OC43 spreads in the mouse CNS (17) the infection with either virus showed similar disseminated patterns in other regions of the brain, such as olfactory bulb and cortex. astrogliosis, considered a marker of inflammation, was also investigated and was detected in the hippocampus. rOC/Us183–241 disseminates more rapidly than rOC/ATCC virus in neuronal cell cultures. in murine primary cultures of CNS, the mutant virus spread more rapidly than the wild-type virus in neurons. the difference in viral spread is similar to those observed by histological examination in the CNS of infected BALB/c mice. neurons (red) were stained with a MAb against microtubule-associated protein 2 (MAP2) and the S viral protein (green) was detected with a rabbit antiserum. rOC/Us183–241 infection increases neuronal cell death in correlation with more infectious particle production. rOC/Us183–241 infection increases neuronal cell death. differentiated human neuroblastoma LA-N-5 cells were infected with rOC/ATCC or rOC/Us183–241 at an MOI of 0.03. infection with the mutant virus led to a significant increase in Bax gene expression between 48 hpi and 72 hpi for both viruses. the level of Bax protein remained stable and did not correlate with the increase in mRNA (Fig. 5B) morphology of LA-N-5 cells in presence of staurosporine (STS) or infected by vesicular stomatis virus (VSV) knockdown of Bax expression with shRNA #1 abolished cytopathic effect induced by STS or VSV. protection of neurons was moderate for population shRNA 2 (mild inhibition of Bax expression) following treatment with STS or VSV. totic factor Bax is functional in the LA-N-5 neuronal cells. it does not play a significant role in HCoV-OC43-induced neuronal cell death. mRNA and protein expression of Bax was analyzed by qPCR and WB. HCoV-OC43 infection induces an increase in RIP1 and RIP3 gene expression. in murine primary cultures of CNS, an increase in RIP1 or RIP3 mRNA was detectable at 48 hpi for both viruses compared to mock infection. rOC/Us183–241 infection tended to transcribe more RIP1 and RIP3 mRNA. RIP3 (lower) mRNA in mixed primary cultures of CNS (A) or differentiated LA-N-5 cells (B) infected with rOC/ATCC or rOC/Us183–241 at the indicated times. results are representative of three independent experiments. inhibition of RIP1 and MLKL protects against neuronal cell death induced by both HCoV-OC43 variants and increases viral replication. a significant increase in RIP1 expression was observed at 48 and 72 hpi. in the LA-N-5 cells transduced with the most efficient shRNA for knocking down RIP1 expression (shRNA #2), almost 50-fold more rOC/ATCC particles and 100-fold more rOC/Us183–241 particles were harvested. a reduction of RIP1 expression delayed neuronal cell death induced by both viruses. phosphorylated MLKL was observed only after infection, whereas in the presence of NSA, both infections showed less phosphorylation of MLKL. to further describe cascade of events possibly associated with necroptosis and involving RIP1 during neuronal cell death induced by HCoV-OC43. we studied the activation of the factor MLKL, a known downstream effector that acts as an ion channel. confocal microscopy revealed that MLKL was at the cell surface after HCoV-OC43 infection. this translocation to the cell surface was more important after infection by the mutant virus. together, these results indicate that MLKL is involved in neuronal cell death following HCoV-OC43 infection. rOC/Us183–241 is more neurovirulent than rOC/ATCC in mice. a variant harboring two point mutations in the viral spike (S) glycoprotein (rOC/Us183–241) showed a significant increase in virus-induced neuronal cell mortality compared to the reference variant (rOC/ATCC) (14). rOC/Us183–241 is more neurovirulent than the reference virus in infected mice. rOC/Us183–241 is more neurovirulent than rOC/ATCC in infected mice. rOC/Us183–241 is more neurovirulent than the reference virus in infected mice. rOC/Us183–241 is one of the first regions where HCoV-OC43 spreads in the mouse CNS (17) rOC/Us183–241 reached this portion of the brain faster than rOC/ATCC. infection with either virus showed similar disseminated patterns in other regions of the brain. mice infected with 102.5 TCID50/10 l of rOC/ATCC or rOC/Us183–241. rOC/Us183–241 disseminates more rapidly than rOC/ATCC virus in neuronal cell cultures. kinetics of viral spread were evaluated by immunofluorescence up to 48 hours postinfection. rOC/Us183/241 disseminates more rapidly than rOC/ATCC in neuronal cell cultures. neurons (red) were stained with a MAb against microtubule-associated protein 2 (MAP2) and the S viral protein (green) was detected with a rabbit antiserum. rOC/Us183–241 infection increases neuronal cell death and produces more infectious particles than rOC/ATCC infection. rOC/Us183–241 infection increases neuronal cell death and produces more infectious particles. apoptosis is one of the best-described cell death pathways. we have previously reported that Bax was relocalized to mitochondria. infection induced a significant increase in Bax gene expression between 48 hpi and 72 hpi for both viruses. in murine mixed primary cultures of CNS or differentiated human neuroblastoma LA-N-5 cells infected with rOC/ATCC or rOC/Us183–241 at the indicated times was performed by Western blot analysis (WB) even the most efficient knockdown of Bax expression did not protect LA-N-5 cells from damages induced by rOC/ATCC or rOC/Us183–241 infection at 48 hpi compared to the control rOC/Us183–241, we measured cell viability and confirmed that Bax knockdown did not confer any protection against neuronal cell death induced during HCoV-OC43 infection. this knockdown led to strong protection against neuronal cell death induced by STS or VSV at 24 hpi in a dose-dependent manner compared to the control population. together, these results indicate that the proapoptotic factor Bax is functional in the LA-N-5 neuron differentiated LA-N-5 cells transduced with different shRNAs were infected with VSV or treated with STS for 24 h. HCoV-OC43 infection induces an increase in RIP1 and RIP3 gene expression. HCoV-OC43 infection increases RIP1 and RIP3 gene expression. levels of RIP1 (upper) or RIP3 (lower) mRNA in murine mixed primary cultures of CNS (A) or differentiated LA-N-5 cells (B) infected with rOC/ATCC or rOC/Us183–241 at the indicated times. western blotting revealed that shRNA #2 was more efficient at knocking down expression of RIP1. inhibition of RIP1 by knockdown decreased the HCoV-OC43-induced cell death at 72 hpi in a dose-dependent manner compared to that of infected LA-N-5 cells transduced with control shRNA (NT) a significant increase in cell-associated mutant infectious viral particles was observed at 48 and 72 hpi. results are representative of three independent experiments. cell viability was measured by PrestoBlue assay. phosphorylated MLKL was observed only after infection. whereas in the presence of NSA, both infections showed less phosphorylation of MLKL. we infected LA-N-5 cells with the reference or mutant virus. the cells were labeled with antibody against the N-terminal epitope of MLKL. these results indicate that MLKL is involved in neuronal cell death. differentiated LA-N-5 cells were infected with rOC/ATCC or rOC/Us183–241 at an MOI of 1. The surface distribution of MLKL (green) and nucleus (blue) were detected by confocal microscopy. for panels A and B, data are represented as means SD. rOC/Us183–241 infection enhanced the unfolded protein response (UPR) and protein synthesis inhibition (13), suggesting that this mutant virus could increase ER stress in neurons associated with neurodegeneration and neuropathogenesis in infected mice. mutations in the viral S protein appear to modulate the neuronal cellular response involving inflammation, neuronal damage, and eventually loss of neurons by RCD activation. HCoV-OC43 infection leads to the production of proinflammatory cytokines. this contributes to enhanced proinflammatory cytokine secretion and to a deleterious neuroinflammation process. neurovirulence of the murine coronavirus MHV-A59 was linked to the excessive production of proinflammatory cytokine secretion. cytomegalovirus (65), myxoma virus (66), vaccinia virus (67) and Epstein-Barr virus (68) all encode viral Bcl-2 homologs that interact with and inhibit Bax activation. HCoV-OC43 infection induces a redox imbalance, promoting translocation of Bax to the mitochondria without any consequences on neuronal cell death. lateral sclerosis (74), Huntington's disease (75), multiple sclerosis (76) and ischemic brain injury (77) may be related to necroptosis activation. expression and activation of these factors are also considered to be a defense mechanism against pathogen invasion (64, 79) several viruses, such as reovirus (81), reovirus (81), IAV (82), CMV, and HSV (83), are known to activate RIP1, RIP expression also results in an increase of cell-associated infectious particle production. expression suggests that RIP1 is activated by neurons in response to the infection as an attempt to restrict viral replication. this suggests necroptosis-like pathways related to RIP1 and MLKL were involved in the cell death induced by HCoV-OC43. infection by HCoV-OC43 induced an ER stress in neurons that initiate RIP1-MLKL-driven necroptosis. inhibition of cyclophilin D, an isomerase acting to modulate the mitochondrial permeability transition pore, has been shown to reduce necroptosis-related cell death in mouse embryonic fibroblasts. is-like pathway (mutant versus wild-type virus), it may induce an excessive neuroinflammation associated with an enhanced release of DAMPs (37, 79), and the cellular response to the infection may become deleterious for the host. challenge will be to target and modulate specific RCD activation without interfering in antiviral responses within the CNS to attenuate the deleterious effect. cells were seeded in RPMI supplemented with 15% (vol/vol) FBS, 10 mM HEPES, 1 mM NaPy, 100 M nonessential amino acids. the next day and every 2 days for a period of 6 days, 10 M all-trans-retinoic acid (Sigma-Aldrich) was added to the same medium supplemented with 10% (vol/vol) FBS. Staurosporine (STS) was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and used to treat LA-N-5 cells at a final concentration of 500 nM. the tissues were incubated overnight at 37°C with gentle tilting to mix. survival curve, body weight variation, and evaluation of clinical scores were evaluated. cells were seeded at approximately 1 105 cells/cm2 and grown on collagen–poly-d-lysine (3:1, for a final concentration of 50 g/ml)-treated glass coverslips for immunofluorescence assay. the viability of LA-N-5 cells was monitored using PrestoBlue. values at 570 nm and 600 nm every hour for 3 h with a microplate reader (Bio-Rad) cell viability was determined according to slope regression analysis for each sample. the primary antibody was the mouse monoclonal antibody (MAb) 4.3E4 (1/2), which was added to each well to detect viral S glycoprotein. wells were incubated at 37°C with 5% CO2 for 2 h and then washed three times with PBS. RNA extraction, cDNA synthesis, and quantitative PCR were performed using the RNeasy minikit (Qiagen) cells were centrifuged at 3,500 rpm for 5 min at 4°C. pellet was resuspended in radioimmunoprecipitation assay buffer. protein concentrations were measured using the bicinchoninic acid protein assay kit. glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GAPDH) proteins were washed three times with TBS-T at RT for 5 min before being incubated with anti-mouse or anti-rabbit secondary antibodies. membranes were visualized by chemiluminescence using Clarity Western ECL substrate (Bio-Rad), and loading was normalized to the housekeeping protein GAPDH. cells were cotransfected with 6 g of each vector per petri dish and Lipofectamine 3000. the supernatant was harvested and lentiviral pseudoparticles were concentrated using the Lenti-X Maxi purification kit (Clontech) after 24 h, the medium was replaced with RPMI containing retinoic acid to complete the differentiation. cells were fixed with 4%, wt/vol, paraformaldehyde (PFA; Fisher) for 30 min at RT. cells were incubated with different primary antibodies, including mouse anti-spike HCoV-OC43 protein (1-10.C3) monoclonal antibody (1/2; hybridoma supernatant), polyclonal rabbit anti-S protein of bovine coronavirus (BCoV; 1/1,000) mice infected (wt or mutant virus) or left uninfected (sham) were perfused with 4%, wt/vol, PFA. whole brains were carefully harvested from mice infected at 5, 7 and 9 days after intracerebral injection of each virus. brain tissues were sectioned using a vibratome (VT1000E; Leica) to yield 60-m sections. all animal experiments were approved by the Institutional Animal Care and Use Ethics Committee (IACUC) of the Institut National de la Recherche Scientifique (INRS) all of the experiments with both wild-type and mutant viruses (S protein with a potential gain of function) were approved by the institutional biosafety committee at INRS. the recombinant wild-type (wt) reference HCoV-OC43 (rOC/ATCC) virus and the recombinant mutant HCoV-OC43 virus (rOC/Us183–241) were generated using a full-length cDNA clone. LA-N-5 cells were infected at a multiplicity of infection (MOI) of 0.2 during 2 h at 37°C. group of 10 mice were subjected to observation on a daily basis for survival and body weight variations over a period of 22 days postinfection. asymptomatic mice were classified as level 0, level 1 was for mice with symptoms of abnormal flexion of the four limbs. level 2 was for mice presenting social isolation, ruffled fur, and hunched backs. cells were seeded at approximately 1 105 cells/cm2 and grown on glass coverslips. the medium was changed every 2 days thereafter, and the cultures were ready for infection after 7 days in culture. the viability of LA-N-5 cells was monitored using PrestoBlue (Life Technologies) through reduction of reagent according to the manufacturer's protocol. labeling reagent was added to primary cultures of mouse CNS seeded in 24-well plates containing 500 l of Neurobasal medium. from each well, 200 l was transferred to 5 new wells of 96-well plates. OD was measured in replicates at 570 nm using a microplate reader. RNA extraction, cDNA synthesis, and quantitative PCR. total RNA from cells was extracted using the RNeasy minikit. cDNA synthesis was performed using a superscript III first-strand kit. 0.05 M Tris containing fresh protease inhibitor cocktail set I. cells were incubated on ice for 20 min and centrifuged at 14,000 rpm for 10 min at 4°C. the supernatants were transferred to a new tube and conserved at 80°C. 5 106 cells were plated in petri dishes precoated with sterile PBS containing 0.1% (vol/vol) gelatin. after 5 min, the medium was replaced by DMEM supplemented with 10% (vol/vol) FBS and then incubated for 96 h at 37°C with 5% CO2. the supernatant was harvested and eluted in sterile PBS. LA-N-5 cells were differentiated into neurons with retinoic acid for 6 days. lentiviral pseudoparticles were added to an MOI of 10. cells were incubated for another 48 h before proceeding to infection with HCoV. al mouse anti-microtubule-associated protein 2 (MAP2) antibody (1/1,000; 556320; BD Biosciences), rabbit anti-glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) antibody (1/1,000; Z0334; Dako), rabbit anti-MLKL (1/200; M6687; Sigma-Aldrich), and rabbit anti-phosphorylated MLKL (1/200; EPR9514; Abcam) cells were incubated for 1 h at sections were incubated with a solution of two droplets of H2O2 in PBS for 10 min at RT. sections were then blocked with a solution of PBS containing 1 droplet of normal horse serum. tissue sections were incubated with primary antibodies for detection of N protein.
